fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categorical homotopy theory

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This book develops abstract homotopy theory from the categorical perspective with a particular focus on examples. Part I discusses two competing perspectives by which one typically first encounters homotopy (co)limits: either as derived functors definable when the appropriate diagram categories admit a compatible model structure, or through particular formulae that give the right notion in certain examples. Emily Riehl unifies these seemingly rival perspectives and demonstrates that model structures on diagram categories are irrelevant. Homotopy (co)limits are explained to be a special case of weighted (co)limits, a foundational topic in enriched category theory. In Part II, Riehl further examines this topic, separating categorical arguments from homotopical ones. Part III treats the most ubiquitous axiomatic framework for homotopy theory - Quillen's model categories. Here, Riehl simplifies familiar model categorical lemmas and definitions by focusing on weak factorization systems. Part IV introduces quasi-categories and homotopy coherence.

A homotopical category is a category equipped with a collection of morphisms W, called the weak equivalences, which contains the isomorphisms and satisfies the two-of-six property (hence is closed under composition and so forms a wide subcategory). A homotopical functor is a functor which preserves weak equivalences; the category of homotopical categories is so defined.
The isomorphisms in any category satisfy the two-of-six property, hence form the minimal homotopical structure on that category.
A class of morphisms S is saturated if it creates isomorphisms under localization C\xrightarrow {Q} C[S^{-1}].
Any saturated class of morphisms W satisfies two-of-six, hence forms a homotopical category.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The isomorphisms satisfy two-of-six and are created by W.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A collection of morphisms W in a category satisfy the two-of-six property if, for any composable triple \bullet \xrightarrow {f} \bullet \xrightarrow {g} \bullet \xrightarrow {h} \bullet , if gf\in W and hg\in W, then so are f, g, h, and hgf.

A collection of morphisms W in a category satisfy the two-of-three property if, for any composable pair \bullet \xrightarrow {f} \bullet \xrightarrow {g} \bullet , then whenever two of f, g, and gf are in W, so is the third.

Let M be a class of maps in a category. Its left orthgonal class {}^\perp M is the class of maps with the left lifting property against M; dually, its right orthogonal class M^\perp is those with the right lifting property against M.

Let M be a class of maps in a category. Its weakly left orthgonal class {}^\rightthreetimes M is the class of maps with the weak left lifting property against M; dually, its right orthogonal class M^\rightthreetimes is those with the weak right lifting property against M.
The copower or tensor E\cdot x of an object x by a discrete category E is the E-indexed coproduct of copies of x.
